newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian call money off day's high, gilts steady.
newsitem.headline: Indian call money off day's high, gilts steady.

text.p: Indian call money ended Monday around 11 percent, off the day's high of 11.5 percent as demand for funds eased in the afternoon, dealers said.
They said rates which were firm during the morning and early afternoon eased off as demand for funds tapered off.
Dealers said most of the day's trade was between 10.90 and 11.25 percent with stray deals at 11.5 percent.
"The firmness in rates was a bit surprising," said a dealer. "It appears that a number of borrowing banks do not have export refinance limits...otherwise rates would be below 11 percent."
Banks can avail refinance against their export credit disbursals from the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) at 11 percent per annum.
Prices of government securities were steady in moderate trade, dealers said.
The 13.40 percent 1999 government of India stock traded at a yield of 13.15 percent against its last traded yield of 13.18.
The 91-day treasury bill auctioned on December 27 at a yield of 8.19 percent was traded on Monday at 8.5 percent, a dealer said.
